definitions_glossary.intima: Innermost layer of arterial wall, in direct contact with blood
definitions_glossary.media: Middle layer of arterial wall, contains smooth muscle and elastic tissue
definitions_glossary.true_lumen: Original, native channel of the aorta
definitions_glossary.false_lumen: New channel created by dissection within the aortic wall
definitions_glossary.entry_tear: Primary intimal tear where blood enters the wall
definitions_glossary.re_entry_tear: Secondary tear where blood exits back to true lumen
definitions_glossary.malperfusion: Inadequate blood supply to organs due to branch vessel compromise

type_a.definition: Any dissection involving the ascending aorta, regardless of entry site

type_b.definition: Dissection involving only the descending aorta (distal to left subclavian)

debakey_classification.type_i: Originates in ascending, propagates to descending
debakey_classification.type_iii: Originates in descending, IIIa = thoracic only, IIIb = extends to abdominal

definition.@value: Tear in aortic intima allowing blood to separate wall layers, creating a false lumen parallel to the true lumen

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Define aortic dissection and distinguish from aortic aneurysm
Explain the Stanford and DeBakey classification systems
Identify the critical difference between Type A and Type B
List major risk factors for aortic dissection
Understand the urgency of Type A dissection
common_errors: Delaying diagnosis by pursuing other workup
Not considering dissection in stroke or leg ischemia
Giving anticoagulation without ruling out dissection
clinical_pearls: Think dissection in any patient with sudden severe chest/back pain + hypertension
Type A = Ascending = Emergency surgery; Type B = Below = Medical management
BP discrepancy between arms is classic but only present in 20-30%
Mortality increases 1-2% per hour in Type A - don't delay for additional tests
